Name: SODIUM LAURYL SULFATE
Synonyms: Sulfuric acid monododecyl ester sodium salt
Description: Sodium dodecyl sulfate is an organic sodium salt that is the sodium salt of dodecyl hydrogen sulfate. It has a role as a detergent and a protein denaturant. It contains a dodecyl sulfate.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Hansch C et al; Exploring QSAR. Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. ACS Prof Ref Book. Heller SR, consult. ed., Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p. 76 (1995) (2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Jun 24, 2014: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm/ (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 71 was calculated for sodium lauryl sulfate(SRC), using a log Kow of 1.6(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Chemicals Inspection and Testing Institute; Biodegradation and bioaccumulation data of existing chemicals based on the CSCL Japan. Japan Chemical Industry Ecology - Toxicology and Information Center. ISBN 4-89074-101-1 (1992) (2) Deschenes L et al; Hydrol Sci J 40: 471-484 (1995) (3) Anderson DJ et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 56: 758-63 (1990)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Sodium lauryl sulfate, present at 100 mg/L, reached 85% of its theoretical BOD in 2 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(1). In 10 days, approximately 60% of sodium lauryl sulfate, present at 10 mg/kg, was mineralized in a creosote-contaminated sandy loam soil; the rate of biodegradation decreased slightly at higher concentrations(2). The biodegradation of sodium lauryl sulfate varied considerably in river water samples collected from four locations of a polluted river at two times(3). The time to removal of approximately 80% of the initial concentration (approximately 25 ppm) of sodium lauryl sulfate ranged from 50-140 hours depending upon the season in which the samples were collected and the inoculum source(3).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Margesin R, Schinner F; Int Biodeterior Biodegradation 41: 139-43 (1998)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Sodium lauryl sulfate biodegradation was noted at 10 °C by diesel-oil degrading cold-adapted soil inocula in mineral medium. Sixteen out of the 29 inocula were capable of degrading 500-1000 mg sodium lauryl sulfate/L within 96 hrs at 10 °C. Three of these were not capable of degrading sodium lauryl sulfate 2000 mg/L(1).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Wagener S, Schink B; Wat Res 21: 615-622 (1987)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: Anaerobic degradation of sodium lauryl sulfate, using anoxic sludge from a wastewater treatment plant and a polluted river as the inoculum, resulted in inhibitory effects at >100 mg/L and >50 mg/L, respectively(1).

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 107

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Jun 24, 2014: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc of sodium lauryl sulfate can be estimated to be 3200(SRC). According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that sodium lauryl sulfate is expected to have slight mobility in soil.
